document.title: Creating Spaces for Listening, Learning, and Sustaining the Inner Lives of Students
document.abstract: This essay explores what it takes to "create a space in the classroom that allows students the freedom to nourish their inner lives," an issue raised by Mary Rose O'Reilly in Radical Presence. The author draws on work in composition studies, education, and her own teaching practices to illustrate the importance of creating such spaces.
document.publication-title: The Journal of the Assembly for Expanded Perspectives on Learning

field.name: acknowledgements
field.value: Gesa E. Kirsch is Professor of English at Bentley College in Waltham, MA. She has written and edited a number of books on feminism and composition, ethics and representation, and research methodology. Recently, she edited Beyond the Archives: Research as a Lived Process (with Liz Rohan).
